content.question:
Stress vs. Anxiety

Stress
 Both Stress and Anxiety
 Anxiety

• Goes away once the situation is resolved. • Can be positive or negative. For example, it may inspire you to meet a deadline, or it may cause you to lose sleep.
 Both stress and anxiety can affect your mind and body. You may experience symptoms such as: • Excessive worry • Uneasiness • Tension • Headaches or body pain • High blood pressure • Loss of sleep
 • Usually involves a persistent feeling of apprehension or dread that doesn't go away and that interferes with how you live your life. • Is constant, even if there is no immediate threat.

According to the information from the table, which statement accurately reflects the relationship between stress and anxiety?

choices.label: Stress primarily results in physical symptoms like headaches and body pain, while anxiety solely causes cognitive symptoms such as excessive worry and uneasiness.
Stress can lead to physical symptoms such as high blood pressure, but the same is not true for anxiety.
Anxiety is usually resolved once the triggering stressor is eliminated, unlike stress, which can persist even after the stressor is removed.
Stress and anxiety have similar physical and cognitive symptoms but represent distinct psychological experiences.

content.answer: Stress and anxiety have similar physical and cognitive symptoms but represent distinct psychological experiences.

skill.text: 3.A: Identify psychology-related concepts in descriptions or representations of data.
